newsArray.title: Nat Sciver-Brunt thrilled to continue Ashes ODI form with record-breaking ton
newsArray.description: The stand-in England captain scored a record-breaking century in her 100th ODI.
newsArray.content: On her 100th ODI and captaining the side in the absence of the unwell Heather Knight, Sciver-Brunt demonstrated a masterclass in controlled aggression to peel off a stunning 66-ball hundred. It was the fastest ton in a women‚Äôs ODI by an England batter ‚Äì eclipsing Charlotte Edwards‚Äô 70-ball effort from March 2012 ‚Äì as the hosts prevailed by a whopping 161 runs to seal a 2-0 series win. Sciver-Brunt holed out for 120 off 74 balls, her third three-figure score in her last four ODI innings, having helped England draw a gripping multi-format Ashes series with back-to-back hundreds in July. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm really happy to bat the way I did and continue with what I was doing against Australia as well,‚Äù Sciver-Brunt said at the post-match presentation ceremony. Sciver-Brunt was rested from the preceding three T20s between the teams, where England suffered a shock defeat, but the 31-year-old has felt the benefit of some downtime in a hectic summer programme. She has been managing a knee problem for several months and played in this series as a specialist batter but anticipates returning to all-rounder duties on England‚Äôs tour of India before Christmas. ‚ÄúThe decision not to bowl post-Ashes was more to give the body a bit of a rest,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm looking forward to picking up the ball again. I want to influence games as much as I can. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the best part of being an all-rounder and fielding for 50 overs and not really being able to influence with the ball was a little bit frustrating but I was happy to have the body break for that. ‚ÄúWhen we play so much cricket through the summer, we probably don‚Äôt need to train too many things, just be right in the mind and body and hopefully continue that mindset that I had (in the Ashes).‚Äù England were bogged down by Sri Lanka‚Äôs spinners in the T20s when batting first and may have feared the worst when Tammy Beaumont and Alice Capsey were dismissed early in a match reduced to 31 overs per side at Grace Road because of rain that led to the start time being pushed back by more than three hours. But Sciver-Brunt exhibited why she is so instrumental, taking on the coterie of off-spinners and slow left-armers, punching with aplomb off the back foot and displaying her full range with fluid drives, pulls, sweeps and one scoop for 18 fours and a single six. Maia Bouchier, featuring in just her third ODI and in her second innings in the format, provided ample support with 95 off only 65 balls. The 24-year-old opener crashed a dozen fours and two sixes in a 193-run stand from just 121 deliveries with Sciver-Brunt. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs a fantastic player,‚Äù England head coach Jon Lewis said of his stand-in captain. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the calmness she brings ‚Äì and I thought we saw that in abundance here. The calmness she brought to Maia in a situation when we were 18 for two, she‚Äôs come out with an authority.‚Äù Sciver-Brunt was the first to three figures but Bouchier could have made sure her team-mate‚Äôs record lasted just a few minutes had she dispatched her 65th ball for six, only to be trapped lbw. ‚ÄúI was absolutely gutted for her that she didn‚Äôt score a hundred because I know that when she does score a hundred, she‚Äôll score a lot of hundreds,‚Äù Lewis added. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs incredibly talented.‚Äù Sciver-Brunt and Bouchier underpinned a mammoth 273 for eight, a total which would have stretched Sri Lanka in a regulation 50-over game and the tourists were never in contention in the chase. They capitulated to 112 all out in 24.5 overs, as Charlie Dean claimed five for 31, her maiden five-wicket haul for England which the off-spinner recognised was built on Sciver-Brunt‚Äôs stunning knock. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs the best all-rounder in the world, the best batter,‚Äù Dean said. ‚ÄúShe brings a lot to the team, she definitely elevates us with her standards alone. ‚ÄúI guess she goes under the radar with her leadership ‚Äì she‚Äôs so calm. We have so many players that can do similar but there‚Äôs only one Nat Sciver-Brunt.‚Äù

newsArray.title: Woakes hails Stokes as 'superhuman' after record knock
creator: Staff Writers
newsArray.description: Teammate Chris Woakes, awed by Ben Stokes' latest record-breaking knock against New Zealand, says the England great has "superhuman" skills.
newsArray.content: Chris Woakes says Ben Stokes' record-breaking 182 has given England a timely reminder of what they can achieve with his "superhuman" skills. Stokes was in rampant form against New Zealand on Wednesday, making the country's highest-ever ODI score in just his third innings since reversing his year-long retirement from the format. With England's World Cup defence less than three weeks away, it was a perfect way for the man who carried them to victory in the 2019 final to prove his sense of occasion once again. Stokes has nothing left to prove on the big stage but watching him bully England's first World Cup opponents with nine sixes and 15 fours sent a wave of energy through the dressing room. England went on to wrap up victory by a huge margin of 181 runs, another reminder that when he is in the side, the whole team walks a little taller. "We obviously see Ben as this superhuman that can do incredible things. We know he can," said Woakes, who picked up the baton with three early wickets in the field. "It was great for the group and brilliant for Ben too. He's an unbelievable cricketer but coming back into the team having retired, it will do his confidence a world of good. "We always have doubts and performance anxieties at the best of times, so it's great for his confidence and great for the team's confidence and belief that we can post huge scores. "It was amazing to be here and play in the game because that was an incredible knock. "He struck it cleaner than anyone else out there. It just shows how good a player he is." Since walking away from 50-over cricket last summer citing workload issues, Stokes has poured his energies into his role as Test captain. Working closely with head coach Brendon McCullum, he has revitalised the red-ball set-up, flipping their fortunes in dramatic fashion and playing out a thrilling drawn Ashes series that gripped the nation. Woakes feels that stepping back into the ranks under Jos Buttler's leadership, and operating as a specialist batter rather than all-action all-rounder, is a good thing for Stokes. "I think him coming back into this team is probably a refreshing feeling for him, without the captaincy on his shoulders. To run the England Test team is a tough job," he said. "He's probably seen this as a breath of fresh air, to play his natural game and be his natural person, which he always does." Sign up for our emails

newsArray.title: Problem of plenty is good: Paras Mhambrey
newsArray.description: "A problem of plenty is always good, we have four quality bowlers out there, we have great options," bowling coach Mhambrey said Thursday of a pace attack led by Jasprit Bumrah and also boasting Mohammed Shami, Mohammed Siraj and Shardul Thakur. There is also all-rounder Hardik Pandya. Ravindra Jadeja, Axar Patel and Kuldeep Yadav hold the spin force.
newsArray.content: Synopsis "A problem of plenty is always good, we have four quality bowlers out there, we have great options," bowling coach Mhambrey said Thursday of a pace attack led by Jasprit Bumrah and also boasting Mohammed Shami, Mohammed Siraj and Shardul Thakur. There is also all-rounder Hardik Pandya. Ravindra Jadeja, Axar Patel and Kuldeep Yadav hold the spin force. Paras Mhambrey India face a "problem of plenty" in their bowling stocks ahead of Sunday's Asia Cup final and the ODI World Cup starting next month, coach Paras Mhambrey said. "A problem of plenty is always good, we have four quality bowlers out there, we have great options," bowling coach Mhambrey said Thursday of a pace attack led by Jasprit Bumrah and also boasting Mohammed Shami, Mohammed Siraj and Shardul Thakur . There is also all-rounder Hardik Pandya. Ravindra Jadeja, Axar Patel and Kuldeep Yadav hold the spin force. "The option of choosing the right combination will depend on what surface we are playing and what opponents we are playing," he added. Indian players including up-and-coming batsman Tilak Varma and T20 star Suryakumar Yadav trained in the nets on the eve of the team's last Super Four match, against Bangladesh in Colombo on Friday. Mhambrey gave little away about the line-up. "We haven't decided on what we will do, but obviously there is an opportunity to give a game to other players since we have qualified for the final," said the former medium-pace bowler. Bangladesh have won just one match at the Asia Cup, but Mhambrey said: "Bangladesh is a good team and we will have to play our best cricket." Don‚Äôt miss out on ET Prime stories! newsArray.title: Asia Cup ground staff have the most thankless job. Here's why
newsArray.description: For a day's labour, groundskeepers are paid 2,000 Sri Lankan rupees (LKR), which is about 550 Indian rupees.
newsArray.content: Synopsis For a day's labour, groundskeepers are paid 2,000 Sri Lankan rupees (LKR), which is about 550 Indian rupees. There is a popular meme that has been doing the rounds of the Internet lately. It features an image of a man sitting in a chair, shoulders sagging, head in his hands. As per the meme, he has the most redundant job in the world: that of a lifeguard at a swimming event at the Olympics. That may well be the most pointless if indeed it exists, but the most thankless job in the world is certainly being a groundskeeper in Sri Lanka . The orange brigade , as they have been nicknamed at the R Premadasa Stadium in Colombo , after the bright tee-shirts they wear, have been rock stars. Around 100 are in deployment at each of the Asia Cup matches, and they have been stretched to breaking point. Playing cricket in Sri Lanka in September is never a great idea, especially if you're hosting matches in Colombo. Hambantota is the driest at this time of the year, but a lack of infrastructure close to the venue - the nearest hotels are approximately 45 minutes away from the ground - ruled that out as an option for this tournament. Dambulla is the next best bet, but the ground was not ready to host international cricket, with some repairs and maintenance being done on the lights. So, Colombo it was, and predictably rain has affected virtually all matches in the Super4 stage. On Thursday, when Sri Lanka took on Pakistan, the rain came just as the toss was about to take place. But, the ground staff were alert and managed to get the entire ground covered in a matter of minutes. The downpour that followed was of Biblical proportions. At one point you could barely see the grandstand at the far end of the ground. At almost no other ground in the world would any cricket have been possible given the ferocity and duration of the precipitation and the volume of water that had fallen. Yet, only five overs a side was lost when play began at 5.15pm. This was possible because the ground staff had covered every square foot of the ground in their inimitable style. Approximately 15 giant rubberised canvas sheets, imported from India, are used at each ground. The staff first protect the pitch. Following this they bring covers to the square and then the outfield. After each set of covers is laid down, the edge is peeled back so the next round fits snugly under, making it impossible for water to seep through. This entire exercise is done like a synchronised dance and each person must know his exact role and perform it without deviation or hesitation. Only after this temporary waterproof seal is in place, the ground staff wait for the rain to stop. Once this happens, they reverse the earlier process, starting from the square, or the 30-yard-circle, pulling the covers towards the ropes so that the water that has pooled is driven out of the ground, where it quickly drains down into underground tanks to be stored for later use. The most incredible thing about the entire ground staff operation is how poorly they are treated. For a day's labour, they are paid 2,000 Sri Lankan rupees (LKR), which is about 550 Indian rupees. For every hour of overtime, they get LKR 200, and this is capped at a maximum of five hours per day. In addition, they get three meals and tea and a snack twice a day. When you consider the fact that the Asia Cup nets each participating nation approximately Rs 120 crore, it's staggering that the men who play such a critical role in ensuring that games are played in the first place and are the best at their profession globally, are paid so little. Fortunately, the Indian team is aware of this situation - as are some other teams - and is likely to make a "goodwill gesture" in the form of a one-off financial contribution, at the end of the tournament. That will certainly help the staff, some of whom are only contracted for this tournament and have other jobs, driving a rickshaw, working in a shop or waiting tables at small restaurants, but it does not provide a permanent solution. newsArray.title: Nat Sciver-Brunt thrilled to continue Ashes ODI form with record-breaking ton
newsArray.description: The stand-in England captain scored a record-breaking century in her 100th ODI.
newsArray.content: On her 100th ODI and captaining the side in the absence of the unwell Heather Knight, Sciver-Brunt demonstrated a masterclass in controlled aggression to peel off a stunning 66-ball hundred. It was the fastest ton in a women‚Äôs ODI by an England batter ‚Äì eclipsing Charlotte Edwards‚Äô 70-ball effort from March 2012 ‚Äì as the hosts prevailed by a whopping 161 runs to seal a 2-0 series win. Sciver-Brunt holed out for 120 off 74 balls, her third three-figure score in her last four ODI innings, having helped England draw a gripping multi-format Ashes series with back-to-back hundreds in July. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm really happy to bat the way I did and continue with what I was doing against Australia as well,‚Äù Sciver-Brunt said at the post-match presentation ceremony. Sciver-Brunt was rested from the preceding three T20s between the teams, where England suffered a shock defeat, but the 31-year-old has felt the benefit of some downtime in a hectic summer programme. She has been managing a knee problem for several months and played in this series as a specialist batter but anticipates returning to all-rounder duties on England‚Äôs tour of India before Christmas. ‚ÄúThe decision not to bowl post-Ashes was more to give the body a bit of a rest,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm looking forward to picking up the ball again. I want to influence games as much as I can. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the best part of being an all-rounder and fielding for 50 overs and not really being able to influence with the ball was a little bit frustrating but I was happy to have the body break for that. ‚ÄúWhen we play so much cricket through the summer, we probably don‚Äôt need to train too many things, just be right in the mind and body and hopefully continue that mindset that I had (in the Ashes).‚Äù England were bogged down by Sri Lanka‚Äôs spinners in the T20s when batting first and may have feared the worst when Tammy Beaumont and Alice Capsey were dismissed early in a match reduced to 31 overs per side at Grace Road because of rain that led to the start time being pushed back by more than three hours. But Sciver-Brunt exhibited why she is so instrumental, taking on the coterie of off-spinners and slow left-armers, punching with aplomb off the back foot and displaying her full range with fluid drives, pulls, sweeps and one scoop for 18 fours and a single six. Maia Bouchier, featuring in just her third ODI and in her second innings in the format, provided ample support with 95 off only 65 balls. The 24-year-old opener crashed a dozen fours and two sixes in a 193-run stand from just 121 deliveries with Sciver-Brunt. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs a fantastic player,‚Äù England head coach Jon Lewis said of his stand-in captain. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the calmness she brings ‚Äì and I thought we saw that in abundance here. The calmness she brought to Maia in a situation when we were 18 for two, she‚Äôs come out with an authority.‚Äù Sciver-Brunt was the first to three figures but Bouchier could have made sure her team-mate‚Äôs record lasted just a few minutes had she dispatched her 65th ball for six, only to be trapped lbw. ‚ÄúI was absolutely gutted for her that she didn‚Äôt score a hundred because I know that when she does score a hundred, she‚Äôll score a lot of hundreds,‚Äù Lewis added. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs incredibly talented.‚Äù Sciver-Brunt and Bouchier underpinned a mammoth 273 for eight, a total which would have stretched Sri Lanka in a regulation 50-over game and the tourists were never in contention in the chase. They capitulated to 112 all out in 24.5 overs, as Charlie Dean claimed five for 31, her maiden five-wicket haul for England which the off-spinner recognised was built on Sciver-Brunt‚Äôs stunning knock. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs the best all-rounder in the world, the best batter,‚Äù Dean said. ‚ÄúShe brings a lot to the team, she definitely elevates us with her standards alone. ‚ÄúI guess she goes under the radar with her leadership ‚Äì she‚Äôs so calm. We have so many players that can do similar but there‚Äôs only one Nat Sciver-Brunt.‚Äù

newsArray.title: Woakes hails Stokes as 'superhuman' after record knock
creator: Staff Writers
newsArray.description: Teammate Chris Woakes, awed by Ben Stokes' latest record-breaking knock against New Zealand, says the England great has "superhuman" skills.
newsArray.content: Chris Woakes says Ben Stokes' record-breaking 182 has given England a timely reminder of what they can achieve with his "superhuman" skills. Stokes was in rampant form against New Zealand on Wednesday, making the country's highest-ever ODI score in just his third innings since reversing his year-long retirement from the format. With England's World Cup defence less than three weeks away, it was a perfect way for the man who carried them to victory in the 2019 final to prove his sense of occasion once again. Stokes has nothing left to prove on the big stage but watching him bully England's first World Cup opponents with nine sixes and 15 fours sent a wave of energy through the dressing room. England went on to wrap up victory by a huge margin of 181 runs, another reminder that when he is in the side, the whole team walks a little taller. "We obviously see Ben as this superhuman that can do incredible things. We know he can," said Woakes, who picked up the baton with three early wickets in the field. "It was great for the group and brilliant for Ben too. He's an unbelievable cricketer but coming back into the team having retired, it will do his confidence a world of good. "We always have doubts and performance anxieties at the best of times, so it's great for his confidence and great for the team's confidence and belief that we can post huge scores. "It was amazing to be here and play in the game because that was an incredible knock. "He struck it cleaner than anyone else out there. It just shows how good a player he is." Since walking away from 50-over cricket last summer citing workload issues, Stokes has poured his energies into his role as Test captain. Working closely with head coach Brendon McCullum, he has revitalised the red-ball set-up, flipping their fortunes in dramatic fashion and playing out a thrilling drawn Ashes series that gripped the nation. Woakes feels that stepping back into the ranks under Jos Buttler's leadership, and operating as a specialist batter rather than all-action all-rounder, is a good thing for Stokes. "I think him coming back into this team is probably a refreshing feeling for him, without the captaincy on his shoulders. To run the England Test team is a tough job," he said. "He's probably seen this as a breath of fresh air, to play his natural game and be his natural person, which he always does." Sign up for our emails

newsArray.title: Problem of plenty is good: Paras Mhambrey
newsArray.description: "A problem of plenty is always good, we have four quality bowlers out there, we have great options," bowling coach Mhambrey said Thursday of a pace attack led by Jasprit Bumrah and also boasting Mohammed Shami, Mohammed Siraj and Shardul Thakur. There is also all-rounder Hardik Pandya. Ravindra Jadeja, Axar Patel and Kuldeep Yadav hold the spin force.
newsArray.content: Synopsis "A problem of plenty is always good, we have four quality bowlers out there, we have great options," bowling coach Mhambrey said Thursday of a pace attack led by Jasprit Bumrah and also boasting Mohammed Shami, Mohammed Siraj and Shardul Thakur. There is also all-rounder Hardik Pandya. Ravindra Jadeja, Axar Patel and Kuldeep Yadav hold the spin force. Paras Mhambrey India face a "problem of plenty" in their bowling stocks ahead of Sunday's Asia Cup final and the ODI World Cup starting next month, coach Paras Mhambrey said. "A problem of plenty is always good, we have four quality bowlers out there, we have great options," bowling coach Mhambrey said Thursday of a pace attack led by Jasprit Bumrah and also boasting Mohammed Shami, Mohammed Siraj and Shardul Thakur . There is also all-rounder Hardik Pandya. Ravindra Jadeja, Axar Patel and Kuldeep Yadav hold the spin force. "The option of choosing the right combination will depend on what surface we are playing and what opponents we are playing," he added. Indian players including up-and-coming batsman Tilak Varma and T20 star Suryakumar Yadav trained in the nets on the eve of the team's last Super Four match, against Bangladesh in Colombo on Friday. Mhambrey gave little away about the line-up. "We haven't decided on what we will do, but obviously there is an opportunity to give a game to other players since we have qualified for the final," said the former medium-pace bowler. Bangladesh have won just one match at the Asia Cup, but Mhambrey said: "Bangladesh is a good team and we will have to play our best cricket." Don‚Äôt miss out on ET Prime stories! newsArray.title: Asia Cup ground staff have the most thankless job. Here's why
newsArray.description: For a day's labour, groundskeepers are paid 2,000 Sri Lankan rupees (LKR), which is about 550 Indian rupees.
newsArray.content: Synopsis For a day's labour, groundskeepers are paid 2,000 Sri Lankan rupees (LKR), which is about 550 Indian rupees. There is a popular meme that has been doing the rounds of the Internet lately. It features an image of a man sitting in a chair, shoulders sagging, head in his hands. As per the meme, he has the most redundant job in the world: that of a lifeguard at a swimming event at the Olympics. That may well be the most pointless if indeed it exists, but the most thankless job in the world is certainly being a groundskeeper in Sri Lanka . The orange brigade , as they have been nicknamed at the R Premadasa Stadium in Colombo , after the bright tee-shirts they wear, have been rock stars. Around 100 are in deployment at each of the Asia Cup matches, and they have been stretched to breaking point. Playing cricket in Sri Lanka in September is never a great idea, especially if you're hosting matches in Colombo. Hambantota is the driest at this time of the year, but a lack of infrastructure close to the venue - the nearest hotels are approximately 45 minutes away from the ground - ruled that out as an option for this tournament. Dambulla is the next best bet, but the ground was not ready to host international cricket, with some repairs and maintenance being done on the lights. So, Colombo it was, and predictably rain has affected virtually all matches in the Super4 stage. On Thursday, when Sri Lanka took on Pakistan, the rain came just as the toss was about to take place. But, the ground staff were alert and managed to get the entire ground covered in a matter of minutes. The downpour that followed was of Biblical proportions. At one point you could barely see the grandstand at the far end of the ground. At almost no other ground in the world would any cricket have been possible given the ferocity and duration of the precipitation and the volume of water that had fallen. Yet, only five overs a side was lost when play began at 5.15pm. This was possible because the ground staff had covered every square foot of the ground in their inimitable style. Approximately 15 giant rubberised canvas sheets, imported from India, are used at each ground. The staff first protect the pitch. Following this they bring covers to the square and then the outfield. After each set of covers is laid down, the edge is peeled back so the next round fits snugly under, making it impossible for water to seep through. This entire exercise is done like a synchronised dance and each person must know his exact role and perform it without deviation or hesitation. Only after this temporary waterproof seal is in place, the ground staff wait for the rain to stop. Once this happens, they reverse the earlier process, starting from the square, or the 30-yard-circle, pulling the covers towards the ropes so that the water that has pooled is driven out of the ground, where it quickly drains down into underground tanks to be stored for later use. The most incredible thing about the entire ground staff operation is how poorly they are treated. For a day's labour, they are paid 2,000 Sri Lankan rupees (LKR), which is about 550 Indian rupees. For every hour of overtime, they get LKR 200, and this is capped at a maximum of five hours per day. In addition, they get three meals and tea and a snack twice a day. When you consider the fact that the Asia Cup nets each participating nation approximately Rs 120 crore, it's staggering that the men who play such a critical role in ensuring that games are played in the first place and are the best at their profession globally, are paid so little. Fortunately, the Indian team is aware of this situation - as are some other teams - and is likely to make a "goodwill gesture" in the form of a one-off financial contribution, at the end of the tournament. That will certainly help the staff, some of whom are only contracted for this tournament and have other jobs, driving a rickshaw, working in a shop or waiting tables at small restaurants, but it does not provide a permanent solution. newsArray.title: Nat Sciver-Brunt thrilled to continue Ashes ODI form with record-breaking ton
newsArray.description: The stand-in England captain scored a record-breaking century in her 100th ODI.
newsArray.content: On her 100th ODI and captaining the side in the absence of the unwell Heather Knight, Sciver-Brunt demonstrated a masterclass in controlled aggression to peel off a stunning 66-ball hundred. It was the fastest ton in a women‚Äôs ODI by an England batter ‚Äì eclipsing Charlotte Edwards‚Äô 70-ball effort from March 2012 ‚Äì as the hosts prevailed by a whopping 161 runs to seal a 2-0 series win. Sciver-Brunt holed out for 120 off 74 balls, her third three-figure score in her last four ODI innings, having helped England draw a gripping multi-format Ashes series with back-to-back hundreds in July. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm really happy to bat the way I did and continue with what I was doing against Australia as well,‚Äù Sciver-Brunt said at the post-match presentation ceremony. Sciver-Brunt was rested from the preceding three T20s between the teams, where England suffered a shock defeat, but the 31-year-old has felt the benefit of some downtime in a hectic summer programme. She has been managing a knee problem for several months and played in this series as a specialist batter but anticipates returning to all-rounder duties on England‚Äôs tour of India before Christmas. ‚ÄúThe decision not to bowl post-Ashes was more to give the body a bit of a rest,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm looking forward to picking up the ball again. I want to influence games as much as I can. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the best part of being an all-rounder and fielding for 50 overs and not really being able to influence with the ball was a little bit frustrating but I was happy to have the body break for that. ‚ÄúWhen we play so much cricket through the summer, we probably don‚Äôt need to train too many things, just be right in the mind and body and hopefully continue that mindset that I had (in the Ashes).‚Äù England were bogged down by Sri Lanka‚Äôs spinners in the T20s when batting first and may have feared the worst when Tammy Beaumont and Alice Capsey were dismissed early in a match reduced to 31 overs per side at Grace Road because of rain that led to the start time being pushed back by more than three hours. But Sciver-Brunt exhibited why she is so instrumental, taking on the coterie of off-spinners and slow left-armers, punching with aplomb off the back foot and displaying her full range with fluid drives, pulls, sweeps and one scoop for 18 fours and a single six. Maia Bouchier, featuring in just her third ODI and in her second innings in the format, provided ample support with 95 off only 65 balls. The 24-year-old opener crashed a dozen fours and two sixes in a 193-run stand from just 121 deliveries with Sciver-Brunt. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs a fantastic player,‚Äù England head coach Jon Lewis said of his stand-in captain. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the calmness she brings ‚Äì and I thought we saw that in abundance here. The calmness she brought to Maia in a situation when we were 18 for two, she‚Äôs come out with an authority.‚Äù Sciver-Brunt was the first to three figures but Bouchier could have made sure her team-mate‚Äôs record lasted just a few minutes had she dispatched her 65th ball for six, only to be trapped lbw. ‚ÄúI was absolutely gutted for her that she didn‚Äôt score a hundred because I know that when she does score a hundred, she‚Äôll score a lot of hundreds,‚Äù Lewis added. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs incredibly talented.‚Äù Sciver-Brunt and Bouchier underpinned a mammoth 273 for eight, a total which would have stretched Sri Lanka in a regulation 50-over game and the tourists were never in contention in the chase. They capitulated to 112 all out in 24.5 overs, as Charlie Dean claimed five for 31, her maiden five-wicket haul for England which the off-spinner recognised was built on Sciver-Brunt‚Äôs stunning knock. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs the best all-rounder in the world, the best batter,‚Äù Dean said. ‚ÄúShe brings a lot to the team, she definitely elevates us with her standards alone. ‚ÄúI guess she goes under the radar with her leadership ‚Äì she‚Äôs so calm. We have so many players that can do similar but there‚Äôs only one Nat Sciver-Brunt.‚Äù

newsArray.title: Woakes hails Stokes as 'superhuman' after record knock
creator: Staff Writers
newsArray.description: Teammate Chris Woakes, awed by Ben Stokes' latest record-breaking knock against New Zealand, says the England great has "superhuman" skills.
newsArray.content: Chris Woakes says Ben Stokes' record-breaking 182 has given England a timely reminder of what they can achieve with his "superhuman" skills. Stokes was in rampant form against New Zealand on Wednesday, making the country's highest-ever ODI score in just his third innings since reversing his year-long retirement from the format. With England's World Cup defence less than three weeks away, it was a perfect way for the man who carried them to victory in the 2019 final to prove his sense of occasion once again. Stokes has nothing left to prove on the big stage but watching him bully England's first World Cup opponents with nine sixes and 15 fours sent a wave of energy through the dressing room. England went on to wrap up victory by a huge margin of 181 runs, another reminder that when he is in the side, the whole team walks a little taller. "We obviously see Ben as this superhuman that can do incredible things. We know he can," said Woakes, who picked up the baton with three early wickets in the field. "It was great for the group and brilliant for Ben too. He's an unbelievable cricketer but coming back into the team having retired, it will do his confidence a world of good. "We always have doubts and performance anxieties at the best of times, so it's great for his confidence and great for the team's confidence and belief that we can post huge scores. "It was amazing to be here and play in the game because that was an incredible knock. "He struck it cleaner than anyone else out there. It just shows how good a player he is." Since walking away from 50-over cricket last summer citing workload issues, Stokes has poured his energies into his role as Test captain. Working closely with head coach Brendon McCullum, he has revitalised the red-ball set-up, flipping their fortunes in dramatic fashion and playing out a thrilling drawn Ashes series that gripped the nation. Woakes feels that stepping back into the ranks under Jos Buttler's leadership, and operating as a specialist batter rather than all-action all-rounder, is a good thing for Stokes. "I think him coming back into this team is probably a refreshing feeling for him, without the captaincy on his shoulders. To run the England Test team is a tough job," he said. "He's probably seen this as a breath of fresh air, to play his natural game and be his natural person, which he always does." Sign up for our emails

newsArray.title: Problem of plenty is good: Paras Mhambrey
newsArray.description: "A problem of plenty is always good, we have four quality bowlers out there, we have great options," bowling coach Mhambrey said Thursday of a pace attack led by Jasprit Bumrah and also boasting Mohammed Shami, Mohammed Siraj and Shardul Thakur. There is also all-rounder Hardik Pandya. Ravindra Jadeja, Axar Patel and Kuldeep Yadav hold the spin force.
newsArray.content: Synopsis "A problem of plenty is always good, we have four quality bowlers out there, we have great options," bowling coach Mhambrey said Thursday of a pace attack led by Jasprit Bumrah and also boasting Mohammed Shami, Mohammed Siraj and Shardul Thakur. There is also all-rounder Hardik Pandya. Ravindra Jadeja, Axar Patel and Kuldeep Yadav hold the spin force. Paras Mhambrey India face a "problem of plenty" in their bowling stocks ahead of Sunday's Asia Cup final and the ODI World Cup starting next month, coach Paras Mhambrey said. "A problem of plenty is always good, we have four quality bowlers out there, we have great options," bowling coach Mhambrey said Thursday of a pace attack led by Jasprit Bumrah and also boasting Mohammed Shami, Mohammed Siraj and Shardul Thakur . There is also all-rounder Hardik Pandya. Ravindra Jadeja, Axar Patel and Kuldeep Yadav hold the spin force. "The option of choosing the right combination will depend on what surface we are playing and what opponents we are playing," he added. Indian players including up-and-coming batsman Tilak Varma and T20 star Suryakumar Yadav trained in the nets on the eve of the team's last Super Four match, against Bangladesh in Colombo on Friday. Mhambrey gave little away about the line-up. "We haven't decided on what we will do, but obviously there is an opportunity to give a game to other players since we have qualified for the final," said the former medium-pace bowler. Bangladesh have won just one match at the Asia Cup, but Mhambrey said: "Bangladesh is a good team and we will have to play our best cricket." Don‚Äôt miss out on ET Prime stories! newsArray.title: Asia Cup ground staff have the most thankless job. Here's why
newsArray.description: For a day's labour, groundskeepers are paid 2,000 Sri Lankan rupees (LKR), which is about 550 Indian rupees.
newsArray.content: Synopsis For a day's labour, groundskeepers are paid 2,000 Sri Lankan rupees (LKR), which is about 550 Indian rupees. There is a popular meme that has been doing the rounds of the Internet lately. It features an image of a man sitting in a chair, shoulders sagging, head in his hands. As per the meme, he has the most redundant job in the world: that of a lifeguard at a swimming event at the Olympics. That may well be the most pointless if indeed it exists, but the most thankless job in the world is certainly being a groundskeeper in Sri Lanka . The orange brigade , as they have been nicknamed at the R Premadasa Stadium in Colombo , after the bright tee-shirts they wear, have been rock stars. Around 100 are in deployment at each of the Asia Cup matches, and they have been stretched to breaking point. Playing cricket in Sri Lanka in September is never a great idea, especially if you're hosting matches in Colombo. Hambantota is the driest at this time of the year, but a lack of infrastructure close to the venue - the nearest hotels are approximately 45 minutes away from the ground - ruled that out as an option for this tournament. Dambulla is the next best bet, but the ground was not ready to host international cricket, with some repairs and maintenance being done on the lights. So, Colombo it was, and predictably rain has affected virtually all matches in the Super4 stage. On Thursday, when Sri Lanka took on Pakistan, the rain came just as the toss was about to take place. But, the ground staff were alert and managed to get the entire ground covered in a matter of minutes. The downpour that followed was of Biblical proportions. At one point you could barely see the grandstand at the far end of the ground. At almost no other ground in the world would any cricket have been possible given the ferocity and duration of the precipitation and the volume of water that had fallen. Yet, only five overs a side was lost when play began at 5.15pm. This was possible because the ground staff had covered every square foot of the ground in their inimitable style. Approximately 15 giant rubberised canvas sheets, imported from India, are used at each ground. The staff first protect the pitch. Following this they bring covers to the square and then the outfield. After each set of covers is laid down, the edge is peeled back so the next round fits snugly under, making it impossible for water to seep through. This entire exercise is done like a synchronised dance and each person must know his exact role and perform it without deviation or hesitation. Only after this temporary waterproof seal is in place, the ground staff wait for the rain to stop. Once this happens, they reverse the earlier process, starting from the square, or the 30-yard-circle, pulling the covers towards the ropes so that the water that has pooled is driven out of the ground, where it quickly drains down into underground tanks to be stored for later use. The most incredible thing about the entire ground staff operation is how poorly they are treated. For a day's labour, they are paid 2,000 Sri Lankan rupees (LKR), which is about 550 Indian rupees. For every hour of overtime, they get LKR 200, and this is capped at a maximum of five hours per day. In addition, they get three meals and tea and a snack twice a day. When you consider the fact that the Asia Cup nets each participating nation approximately Rs 120 crore, it's staggering that the men who play such a critical role in ensuring that games are played in the first place and are the best at their profession globally, are paid so little. Fortunately, the Indian team is aware of this situation - as are some other teams - and is likely to make a "goodwill gesture" in the form of a one-off financial contribution, at the end of the tournament. That will certainly help the staff, some of whom are only contracted for this tournament and have other jobs, driving a rickshaw, working in a shop or waiting tables at small restaurants, but it does not provide a permanent solution.
